page.name: Self-Study Delivery Model
page.intro: The Moodle activities and resources listed below reflect how the sample lesson plan was organized for a facilitated instructional delivery model. Feel free to edit, delete or hide these items.
page.content:
If you’d like your users to be able to move through your course in a non-facilitated fashion you’ll need to set up your content in a way that provides as much automation as possible. That means that every time a student interacts with your content you’ll need to provide some type of interaction that allows for automated and immediate feedback based on their responses. 

That works great for formative types of assessments but can be challenging for more summative kinds of projects and responses like essay questions, projects and higher-level thinking types of responses. In these kinds of cases you’ll want to include opportunities for self-reflection. It requires opportunities for students to think about their thinking and what they have learned so that they can start to apply it to their current situations.

Both types of feedback are valuable and can enhance student learning. In the example that follows you’ll see how a lesson can be created in Moodle that allows for more of this type of delivery. Notice the differences between the other two methods that require more instructor led options.

It takes a bit longer to set up these kinds of elements in a course but results in an effective learning experience for your learners.
